awd_titl_txt: Network-scale streamflow intermittence controls on dissolved organic carbon concentrations and processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Streams are important in the cycling of carbon. Almost half of the carbon in watersheds enter streams and rivers where it is converted to a carbon gas or transported downstream. Understanding of these processes come largely from studying continually flowing streams and rivers. Nearly 60% of streams in the United States are intermittent or ephemeral, and all stream and river networks have intermittent streamflow in their contributing networks. Yet little is known about the role that these periodically dry streams play in the processing and movement of carbon through the stream network. This award will address the question of how and when do spatial and temporal patterns of intermittence affect carbon concentrations and characteristics. The researchers will explore flow intermittence effects on dissolved organic carbon and the relative influence of legacy effects of drying during conditions when instream processes control dissolved organic carbon (e.g., growing season) and via connectivity to terrestrial sources during conditions when dissolved organic carbon is typically controlled by flow (e.g., high flows). The broader impacts include training of students, working with local watershed managers, coordinating with research networks, and producing a museum exhibit.

Network scale approaches to understanding stream carbon cycling often make assumptions that are not appropriate for intermittent networks (e.g., homogeneous instream processing rates), and continental and global assessments of stream carbon cycling ignore the role of these streams, potentially missing a major component of the global carbon cycle. This award will transform approaches to thinking about streamflow intermittence and its effects on carbon cycling and transport by integrating network thinking and intermittency effects on biogeochemistry. This award will develop the conceptual and empirical basis for understanding when, where, and how streamflow intermittence affects instream process rates, connectivity to upstream carbon sources, and carbon concentrations and export. The research has two specific aims: Aim 1: Assess spatial and temporal effects of streamflow intermittence on spatial patterns of dissolved organic carbon. This will be accomplished through combining spatially extensive continuous flow presence/absence monitoring with detailed synoptic characterization of dissolved organic carbon concentrations and characteristics across an intermittent stream network. Aim 2: Assess how and when intermittence affects instream process rates and instream process controls on dissolved organic carbon concentrations. The researchers will use high-frequency monitoring of streamflow, dissolved organic carbon concentrations, and instream metabolism. The research will lay the groundwork for integrating heterogeneity into network models of stream carbon cycling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When people are asked to think of a stream, they often imagine water flowing through a channel. Yet, at least half of streams and rivers across the globe are intermittent, meaning that they cease to flow during part of the year. Because these are such a large fraction of all streams, it is important to understand how stream drying and rewetting affect ecosystems, including how these streams store, use and transport carbon. We focused our research on a small watershed in southeastern Idaho to ask: how does stream drying affect where organic carbon ? which includes decomposing leaf litter, for example ? in streams comes from, how it changes while in the stream, and how much leaves the ecosystem?

 

We used two approaches to address this question. First, we installed more than 125 sensors across the stream network to measure when streams were flowing and when they were dry. This allowed us to describe the patterns of stream drying at each site, and how those patterns varied along the stream network. We found that this network included sites that were wet all the time, those that were dry nearly all of the time, and a range of behaviors between. To understand how these streamflow patterns related to organic carbon, we collected samples at 135 sites across the stream network three times during different flow conditions (high spring flows during snowmelt, lower summer flows, and low flows in the fall). We used the optical properties of these samples to infer where the carbon came from. Although we expected stream drying patterns to lead to differences in organic matter sources and transformations, we found that these effects were relatively small compared to seasonal patterns. In the spring, organic matter came mainly from hillslope soils, and by summer and fall, more of the carbon was produced by algae in the stream, and from microbes decomposing organic matter, like leaf litter, in the stream. Interestingly, streams that dried had more microbial organic matter than perennial streams. 

 

The other approach we used to address this question was to install sensors that collected data every 15 minutes in three reaches along the stream that had different stream flow patterns. With these sensors, we observed that organic matter changed on timescales from hours to years. In line with our extensive sampling results, we found that sources and processing of organic material varied between intermittent and perennial streams from spring to summer, and at low flows, intermittent streams have high concentrations of organic matter and high rates of organic matter processing. 

 

Overall, our results suggest that organic matter sources and processing are affected by stream drying, but the effect can vary among years and seasons depending on flow conditions. During wet years, perennial sites can support more instream production of organic matter, while during drought years, intermittent reaches are sites of heightened microbial processing of organic matter. 

 

This project provided support for two MS students and involved three additional graduate and seven undergraduate students. Results from this work have been presented at regional (3) and national (3) meetings. We have 1 published paper with 1 additional manuscript in review, and 3 papers in preparation to submit to peer-reviewed journals.
